title: The Role of Decentralized Exchanges in Monero’s Growth
keyQuestions: Why did major centralized exchanges delist Monero (XMR)?
How do KYC rules and regulations push users toward decentralized swaps?
What makes Monero difficult to monitor (stealth addresses, RingCT, ring signatures)?
What are the practical pros and cons of swapping XMR via DEX and instant swap services?
How can users reduce risk when swapping privacy coins?
quickSteps: Understand the trade-off: privacy vs. the restrictions of regulated centralized venues.
Choose a non-custodial swap route when you want self-custody and fewer account barriers.
Verify coin/network details and confirm amounts before sending funds.
Start with a small test swap if you’re using a new venue or route.
Use basic hygiene: clean device, verified links, and secure wallet backups.

issueRouting.start: If you want to obtain XMR after exchange delistings, start by choosing between custodial convenience and non-custodial privacy-preserving swaps.

branches.if: You want maximum convenience and are fine with KYC/monitoring
then: Use a regulated centralized platform where XMR access is still available in your region.
Expect more checks, limits, and potential delays.
Withdraw to a wallet you control after the trade.

branches.if: You prioritize privacy and self-custody for XMR swaps
then: Use a decentralized or non-custodial swap service to avoid custodial exposure.
Double-check addresses and required transaction fields before sending.
Keep records (TXIDs) and follow the venue’s status page if a swap is delayed.

riskNotes: Regulatory pressure can change access to privacy coins on centralized venues quickly.
Counterparty and custody risk exist on centralized exchanges, even with strong brands.
Execution risk: thin liquidity or network congestion can affect swap timing and price.
Phishing risk: fake “DEX links” and impersonated support are common—verify URLs.
